VOL. XV, NO. 14.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 16, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

LYNN NEXT SEASON

CONCERT GREAT SUCCESS

FOOTBALL JOLLIFICATION

STILL IT GROWS

Football Coaches Reappointed—Meyer
Gives Place to Raleigh in Lacrosse —
Important Business Transacted.

Belair Takes to the Instrumental Clubs
and Boys Enjoy Pleasant .1 rip
and Delightful Dance.

Players Given Sweaters at Rousing Meeting—Short Talks, Sweet Music
and Snappy Yells.

Unsolicited Contributions Bringing Fund
Up—Subscriptions Made For Library
in Professor Elliott's Honor.

very important meeting of the
University athletic board was held
last Monday afternoon in the
trophy room. Questions concerning every branch of Hopkins athletics were brought up and discussed.
Chief of these was the matter
of coaches for next year's football
team. Following the expectations
of the student body, Coaches Lynn
and Sieber were re-elected to train
the squad. This decision was received with enthusiasm by the students; Lynn and Sieber turned out
a first-class team last year, and it
seemed by far the best policy to
retain them and their system of
coaching for next year.
The schedule for Hopkins football next year includes teams much
stronger than heretofore, and the
retention of last year's coaches assures that the greatest things possible will be done with the suad.
A problem to the football authorities next fall will be the getting
together of the men early in the
fall for practice. The schedule is
early, and we want to make as good
a showing as possible in our first
game—that with the Navy. Hopkins has the disadvantage of starting later than most of the colleges,
and consequently the squad will
have .to get together well before
college opens in the fall.
Lacrosse enthusiasts received a
shock when head coach Charles A.
Meyer presented his resignation.
He stated that, owing to pressure
of studies and laboratory work, he
was unable to devote the necessary
time to lacrosse. The resignation
was accepted with reluctance. In
his place was appointed G. Pitts
Raleigh, one of the strongest of last
year's players. Raleigh, like Meyer, is a defense player, and thus the
general composition of the coaching body will not be essentially
changed. Raleigh is an excellent
man for coach, and he is expected
to turn out the regulation Hopkins championship lacrosse team.
Owing to press of business, two
assistants were elected to help
Manager Makel. They are John
T. Burgan, '12, and Julian H.
Marshall, '13.
The base ball team has not vet
been organized, since a coach has
not yet been selected. The athletic
board considered this matter and
finally left it to the base ball advisory committee, consisting of Mr.
B. Howard Griswold, Jr., and Dr.

The Glee and Instrumental Clubs
of the University gave a concert at
Belair on Saturday evening, January 14. The concert was a success
in every way and the house was
packed with a large and appreciative audience. Several encores
were given. The solos by Mr. Conrad Ulig and Mr. Thomas De C.
Ruth, Stollenwerck's piano solo,
and the trio for violin, cello, and
piano, by Messrs. Ray, Gminder,
and Warner were especially fine.
The members of the club were
most delightfully entertained at
the houses of the various patronesses.
Those taking the trip were: J.
R. Ulig, H. Leland, H. B. Dornblazer, W. C. Haupt, 0. K.
Schmeid, S. White, J. N. Stockett,
E. D. Martin, G. M. Gillet, F. Leland, M. Coblentz, J. H. Marston,
Jr., E. 0. Hulbert, E. C. Stollenwerck, C. L. Warner, W. 0. Weyforth, L. L. Jacobs, L. Breuninger,
J. T. King, Jr., H. B. Hering, H.
H. Lloyd, B. Tappan, T. De C.
Ruth, W. Ray, W. F. Geissel, H.
M. Wagner, C. J. Weber, S. S.
Merrick, M. H. Laucheimer, R.
Jenkins, and R. Gminder.
At the close of the concert the
members of the club were entertained with a dance, given in their
honor by the people of Belair.
This proved one of the most enjoyable functions imaginable, and impressed the visitors with the hospitality of their reception.

The annual football "blow-out"
was held in the gymnasium, Thursday evening, January 12. Although
"the proceedings" were scheduled
to begin at 8 o'clock, it was 8.35
before a crowd of about one hundred football enthusiasts had assembled, and President Holmes, of
the Athletic Board, called the meeting to order.
Mr. Homes said in opening, that
he had a string of apoligies to make
for a number of those who were
absent, among whom were Mr.
Griswold, and Dr. Abercrombie,
both being kept away on account
of sickness. President Holmes also
said that he had been requested to
congratulate the football team by

complaining about Hopkins using
her - graduate men. He said he
wished to congratulate the team
to show there was no hard feeling.

On Wednesday, Secretary French
returned from Atlantic City and
the committee began work anew.
The amount subscribed this week
is very small when we compare
it with the large sums that were
coming in just prior to December
31. The amount this week, $7,0oo,
is nearly all unsolicited, and is
therefore all the more welcome.
The committee is recapitulating
and is laying out new. lines of work
which will soon be actively entered
upon. It has been positively announced that the second rnillion
would be on hand on ,Commemoration Day. The fund now stands
$1,167,000.
One of the features of the week's
work was the inauguration of an
A. Marshall Elliott Fund. This
fund is to be used for the maintenance and augumentation of the
library recently presented to the
University by the late Dr. Elliott.
This library will be known as the
A. Marshall Elliott Library. Already more than $2,0oo of this fund
is on hand. Some of the large contributions
of the week were:

The ladies.'committee has determined to extend its sphere of influence and its members will begin
a campaign among all the ladies'
organizations of the State. With
such willing workers there is no
doubt that the President can make
a very gratifying announcement on
Commemoration Day.
Makel, of the lacrosse team, in
the absence of Hering, acted as yell
leader, and as each man came forward he was given a rousing cheer.
Each member of the team was also
cheered.
The Glee Club sang several
songs, which, in spite of the fact
that many of the men were absent,
were very good.
After the last song by the Glee
Club, President Holmes invited the
gentlemen present to step to the
rear of the room, where "refreshments would be pushed through the
window."

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 16, 1911.

As the season of the class
banquets approaches, THE NEWSLETTER wishes to voice a protest
against any repetition of the unfortunate feuds that have so often
marred those occasions. College
traditions and local customs, it is
true, are sadly lacking at Hopkins,
and we should be among the last to
decry any prank that could supply
this want; but the class banquet
riots %aye proved too expensive,
too injurious to the reputation of
the undergraduates about Baltimore, and too unpopular with the
dean and the police to be permitted
to pass down in tradition for the
emulation of future undergraduates. \\Then we get to Homewood, perhaps some arrangements
will be made for an annual chinasmashing fest on our own campus
in decent privacy without any
frantic landlords or spoil-sport
policemen to interfere. In the
meanwhile, however, it is best
to be satisfied with peaceable
banquets.
We regret to see that no one
seems ready to accept those thankless but necessary jobs which have
so long been calling for applicants
on the bulletin boards. The glory
that attaches to a position as assist-'
ant manager of the track team may
not be great when compared with
the work that is expected of such
functionaries. Freshmen and others
should remember, however, that
the road to managerships lies
through the humbler positions.
The man with experience is always
sought to take charge of managing
the big teams, and faithful work
in previous years never fails to
count. Playing on the scrubs is

UPHOLDS ROOSEVELT PLAN

FRESHMEN SEEK LAURELS

Holt Believes in Peace, But Advocates
Armament—Marburg Re-elected
President of Society.

Working Hard to Win Dual Meet With
Sophs—Wells Elected Captain—
Class Numerals Awarded.

The second annual meeting of
the Maryland Peace Society was
held in McCoy Hall last Tuesday
evening. The first part of the
meeting was devoted to the election
of officers and the transaction of
other yearly business, the second
part to a lecture by Mr. FIamilton
Holt, of New York, managing editor of the Independent.
The officers of last year—Theodore Marburg, president; Ed. C.
Wilson, secretary; and Richard J.
White, treasurer—were unanimously re-elected.
Mr. Holt began his lecture by
quoting the opinions of various great
men on .the peace movement, pro
and con; and, after a few pleasantries, remarked that the sanest
attitude for the present is that held
by Mr. Roosevelt—international
peace is an admirable end toward
which to strive, but until it can be
attained, national armaments are
indispensible. He then traced the
amazing progress made by the two
Hague conferences, and recounted
the little-known labors of Mr. F.
W. Holls, without whose earnest
efforts, he stated, the first conference would have been a failure,
and the Permanent Court never
established. Since the close of that
first conference in 1899, a new era,
he said, has dawned for international arbitration.
Mr. Molt's ideal seems to be a
union of all nations, on the basis
of the union of the North American States; and in the present condition of things he professes to see
the beginning of such a union. The
Hague Conferences, which, it is
now assured, will be held in the
future at regular intervals, he likens
to the old Congress of the Confederacy; in the new Court of Arbitral Justice, which, thanks to., the
zeal of Secretary Knox, is soon to
be established, he sees an image of
our Supreme Court; and therefore
there wants nothing save an international executive, which he thinks
will some day surely be realized,
to the fulfillment of the splendid
dream of the last two lines of
Locksley Hall.
r. Holt, after completing his
lecture, showed some very interesting views of the Hague, and the
surrounding country, portraits of
some of the great peace advocates,
and several amusing cartoons from
the press of various nations.

At a meeting of the freshman
class last Monday afternoon, Clifford A. Wells, of Toronto, Can.,
was elected captain of the 1914
track team with Herbert E. Catlin,
manager. Immediately after being
elected captain, Wells issued a call
for candidates, and there were a
number of freshmen training with
the 'varsity squad every afternoon
last week.
Wells and Sutton are twO runners
who will make the sophomores
hustle in the distance events. Dorsey, Catlin, White, and Barton are
among the candidates for the
dashes. Hinrichs, Wells, Coblentz,
and Liebensperger are training for
the high jump. Yost and Krumrein will probably represent the
freshmen in the broad jump.
Riley and Schreiber will give the
sophomore crack weight throwers
—Novak and Pieper—a hard fight
in the shot-put. Chenoweth, who
played center on the freshman football team, is also showing up well
in practice with the shot.
The freshmen awarded the class
numbers to their class football
squad and to those who succeeded
in getting hands on the cane in the
cane rush. Those who received the
numerals. were: E. Riley, D. Riley,
Dorsey, Catlin, W. Sutton, White,
Howell, Bryan, Hill, Chenoweth,
Schreiber, Barton, Yost, Randall,
Campbell, Hanzsche, Holliday,
Liebensperger, Coblentz, a n d
Bridgman.

Haresfoot Club Try-Out.

The Haresfoot Club will hold a
reading rehearsal and try-out for
parts, on Tuesday evening, at the
Delta Phi house. Several parts
will be given to new men, and
freshmen, especially, are urged to
try for the Club.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 16, 1911

Pennants, Gymnasium Supplies,

BOOK REVIEWS

$1,000 FOR ESSAYISTS

History of Socialism in the United
States. (New Edition.) By Morris
Hillquit. New York: Funk & Wagnalls
Company. Price $1,50 net.

Anti-Saloon League Will Pay for Papers
on What the Liquor Revenue
Costs Baltimore.

With a Socialist mayor, a representative in Congress and a hundren minor state officials in various
parts . of the country, the third
political party in the United States
can, after years of ceaseless effort,
point to something accomplished.
There has been no one event respon-.
sible for the election of these men.
A steady movement which has for
the most part been gradually gaining force is the cause of these
election results.
The new edition of Hillquit's
work which has for seven years
served as the authority on the
Socialist movement in America is
at this juncture peculiarly oppoctune. It is a thoroughly able study
of wide scope and of great theoretical and sociological as well as •
historical value. It traces the
origin and development of Socialism through the many transient
communistic experiments which
have been urged by political dreamers, with a sympathetic treatment
brings it down to the present day,
when the movement is attracting
n:ore attention than it has ever before been accorded in political
circles.
The future, according to Mr.
Hillquit, is an especially bright one.
He believes that "the industrial development is irresistibly preparing,
the ground for a large and vigorous Socialistic movement," and
that if the American voters could
be persuaded that the cause is not
a hopeless one, it would immediately be established as a permanent, important, and perhaps dominant factor in American politics.
But in the concluding paragraph
of the book, there is an admission
which seems to destroy somewhat
the force of the optimistic conclusions. "Many, of the measures," Mr.
Hillquit says, "of industrial, social
and political reform, originally advocated exclusively by the Socialists, are gradually being forced into
the platforms of other parties and
organizations." What is there to
keep us from believing that the
end will be reached by these
means? The history of government
indicates that some of the desires of
the Socialists will ultimately be attained. Soule, such as the income
tax, municipal ownership, and the
initiative and referendum are already in existence. But is it not
more probable that all of these reforms will be gradually brought
about through the agency of the
regular parties than by an organization whose methods and desires are
not at the present time in sympathy
with the spirit of America?
L. R.

University students have an excellent opportunity to add to the information available upon a question
of great local importance and at
the same time to secure an unusual
reward by taking advantage of the
offer made by the Anti-Saloon
League of Maryland of prizes
amounting to $1,000 for the best
essays on what the liquor revenue
costs the City of Baltimore. The
contest closes on April I, 1911,
giving contestants two months and
a half yet in which to work..
So far the number of papers submitted to the League has not come
up to anticipations. "We are
anxious," said Mr. 'William H. Anderson, the secretary, "that there
shall be a goodly number of candidates with real ability, and not
enough have shown up yet to make
it by any means improbable that
any good man who tries may get
the prize."
The conditions of the contest are
as follows:
A prize of five hundred dollars
($500) for the best essay, and
three additional prizes of $250,
$150 and Slop respectively for the
three next best essays on:
"What it costs the people of Baltimore (I) morally, (2) physically,
(3) mentally, (4) financially, and
(5) industrially to secure the million dollars a year which the city
now receives from the liquor traffic
under the high license law."
The contest is open to any person
anywhere except salaried employees of the Anti-Saloon League
of -Maryland. Essays must not exceed 5,000 words. The number of
words must be indicated, and, other
things being equal, brevity will be
considered in making the award.
Facts will count for more than
mere argument. Essays must be
typewritten, double spaced, with
ample margin, on one side of plain
inches, with
white paper 82x
name and address of the writer
securely attached in a sealed envelope.
Essays must be received, postage
-hilly prepaid, by Rev. J. F. Heisse,
D. D., Chairman of the Headquarters Committee, at the League
office, Sol American Building, Baltimore, Md., on or before April
1, 1911. All essays shall become
the property of the League. The
decision will be made by the Headquarters Committee of the AntiSaloon League, or by judges designated by them, and will be announced and the prizes paid as soon
as the essays can be examined and
a decision reached. -

ATHLETIC RECORDS FIXED
Committee Reports on Track and Field
Performances by Hopkins Athletes—
Holders of Records and
the Figures.

Hopkins track and field athletic
records have been authoritatively established by the report of the special
committee which since its appointment in 1907 has been engaged
in investigating the performances
of the athletes of the University
for the purpose of compiling
official records for the athletic
board.
The report in full is too long
to publish here. The following
quotation will explain the nature of
the work of the committee:
"The earlier records—i. e., before 1896—if any there were, do
not seem to be preserved in any
obtainable form. This date, however, corresponds practically with
the beginning of the University's
activity in track and field athletics,
and for that reason is taken by
your committee as a starting point
the authenticated performances.
"Out of the material at hand
various difficulties presented themselves, as far as the correctness of
the different marks was concerned.
It became necessary to determine,
as accurately as possible, whether
the track events were properly
timed or judged, as well as to discover if the field performances
were measured with precision and
accuracy—all of which necessitated
the examination of many old programs, records and the like. It is
believed, however, that the results
arrived at represent, as nearly as
possible, the present state of performances. For the correction of
any, the smallest, details your committee will be extremely grateful.
Respectfully submitted,
"G. W. STUART,
"J. H. HUNM,
"J. T. ENGLAND."

German Author To Speak.

Tomorrow (Tuesday evening)
at 8 o'clock there will be a lecture
in McCoy Hall by Ernst Ludwig
reiherr von Wolzogen on "Das
Deutsche Theatre der Gegenwart."
Herr von Wolzogen is a novelist
and dramatist of note and it is
fortunate that we may have the
pleasure of hearing him.
Herr von Wolzogen was born
in Breslau in 1855. From 1876-79
he studied in Strasburg and Leipsic
and later spent a number of years
in Weimar. He went to Berlin in
1882, later to Munich and is now
resident in Darmstadt. He has distinguished himself by his bright
and easily-flowing stories and by
his comedies. Some of his works
are: "Um 13 Uhr in der Christnacht," "Das Dritte Geschlect,"
"Feursnot," (set to music by
Richard Strauss), "Verse aus
Meinem Leben." He has written
also many critical and literary
studies.

very important meeting of the
University athletic board was held
last Monday afternoon in the
trophy room. Questions concerning every branch of Hopkins athletics were brought up and discussed.
Chief of these was the matter
of coaches for next year's football
team. Following the expectations
of the student body, Coaches Lynn
and Sieber were re-elected to train
the squad. This decision was received with enthusiasm by the students; Lynn and Sieber turned out
a first-class team last year, and it
seemed by far the best policy to
retain them and their system of
coaching for next year.
The schedule for Hopkins football next year includes teams much
stronger than heretofore, and the
retention of last year's coaches assures that the greatest things possible will be done with the suad.
A problem to the football authorities next fall will be the getting
together of the men early in the
fall for practice. The schedule is
early, and we want to make as good
a showing as possible in our first
game—that with the Navy. Hopkins has the disadvantage of starting later than most of the colleges,
and consequently the squad will
have .to get together well before
college opens in the fall.
Lacrosse enthusiasts received a
shock when head coach Charles A.
Meyer presented his resignation.
He stated that, owing to pressure
of studies and laboratory work, he
was unable to devote the necessary
time to lacrosse. The resignation
was accepted with reluctance. In
his place was appointed G. Pitts
Raleigh, one of the strongest of last
year's players. Raleigh, like Meyer, is a defense player, and thus the
general composition of the coaching body will not be essentially
changed. Raleigh is an excellent
man for coach, and he is expected
to turn out the regulation Hopkins championship lacrosse team.
Owing to press of business, two
assistants were elected to help
Manager Makel. They are John
T. Burgan, '12, and Julian H.
Marshall, '13.
The base ball team has not vet
been organized, since a coach has
not yet been selected. The athletic
board considered this matter and
finally left it to the base ball advisory committee, consisting of Mr.
B. Howard Griswold, Jr., and Dr.

The Glee and Instrumental Clubs
of the University gave a concert at
Belair on Saturday evening, January 14. The concert was a success
in every way and the house was
packed with a large and appreciative audience. Several encores
were given. The solos by Mr. Conrad Ulig and Mr. Thomas De C.
Ruth, Stollenwerck's piano solo,
and the trio for violin, cello, and
piano, by Messrs. Ray, Gminder,
and Warner were especially fine.
The members of the club were
most delightfully entertained at
the houses of the various patronesses.
Those taking the trip were: J.
R. Ulig, H. Leland, H. B. Dornblazer, W. C. Haupt, 0. K.
Schmeid, S. White, J. N. Stockett,
E. D. Martin, G. M. Gillet, F. Leland, M. Coblentz, J. H. Marston,
Jr., E. 0. Hulbert, E. C. Stollenwerck, C. L. Warner, W. 0. Weyforth, L. L. Jacobs, L. Breuninger,
J. T. King, Jr., H. B. Hering, H.
H. Lloyd, B. Tappan, T. De C.
Ruth, W. Ray, W. F. Geissel, H.
M. Wagner, C. J. Weber, S. S.
Merrick, M. H. Laucheimer, R.
Jenkins, and R. Gminder.
At the close of the concert the
members of the club were entertained with a dance, given in their
honor by the people of Belair.
This proved one of the most enjoyable functions imaginable, and impressed the visitors with the hospitality of their reception.

The annual football "blow-out"
was held in the gymnasium, Thursday evening, January 12. Although
"the proceedings" were scheduled
to begin at 8 o'clock, it was 8.35
before a crowd of about one hundred football enthusiasts had assembled, and President Holmes, of
the Athletic Board, called the meeting to order.
Mr. Homes said in opening, that
he had a string of apoligies to make
for a number of those who were
absent, among whom were Mr.
Griswold, and Dr. Abercrombie,
both being kept away on account
of sickness. President Holmes also
said that he had been requested to
congratulate the football team by
a Mr. Yellott, of Belair, the St.
Johns man who had been the author of the letters in The News
complaining about Hopkins using
her - graduate men. He said he
wished to congratulate the team

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 16, 1911.

As the season of the class
banquets approaches, THE NEWSLETTER wishes to voice a protest
against any repetition of the unfortunate feuds that have so often
marred those occasions. College
traditions and local customs, it is
true, are sadly lacking at Hopkins,
and we should be among the last to
decry any prank that could supply
this want; but the class banquet
riots %aye proved too expensive,
too injurious to the reputation of
the undergraduates about Baltimore, and too unpopular with the
dean and the police to be permitted
to pass down in tradition for the
emulation of future undergraduates. \\Then we get to Homewood, perhaps some arrangements
will be made for an annual chinasmashing fest on our own campus
in decent privacy without any
frantic landlords or spoil-sport
policemen to interfere. In the
meanwhile, however, it is best
to be satisfied with peaceable
banquets.
We regret to see that no one
seems ready to accept those thankless but necessary jobs which have
so long been calling for applicants
on the bulletin boards. The glory
that attaches to a position as assist-'
ant manager of the track team may
not be great when compared with
the work that is expected of such
functionaries. Freshmen and others
should remember, however, that
the road to managerships lies
through the humbler positions.
The man with experience is always
sought to take charge of managing
the big teams, and faithful work
in previous years never fails to
count. Playing on the scrubs is

UPHOLDS ROOSEVELT PLAN

FRESHMEN SEEK LAURELS

Holt Believes in Peace, But Advocates
Armament—Marburg Re-elected
President of Society.

Working Hard to Win Dual Meet With
Sophs—Wells Elected Captain—
Class Numerals Awarded.

The second annual meeting of
the Maryland Peace Society was
held in McCoy Hall last Tuesday
evening. The first part of the
meeting was devoted to the election
of officers and the transaction of
other yearly business, the second
part to a lecture by Mr. FIamilton
Holt, of New York, managing editor of the Independent.
The officers of last year—Theodore Marburg, president; Ed. C.
Wilson, secretary; and Richard J.
White, treasurer—were unanimously re-elected.
Mr. Holt began his lecture by
quoting the opinions of various great
men on .the peace movement, pro
and con; and, after a few pleasantries, remarked that the sanest
attitude for the present is that held
by Mr. Roosevelt—international
peace is an admirable end toward
which to strive, but until it can be
attained, national armaments are
indispensible. He then traced the
amazing progress made by the two
Hague conferences, and recounted
the little-known labors of Mr. F.
W. Holls, without whose earnest
efforts, he stated, the first conference would have been a failure,
and the Permanent Court never
established. Since the close of that
first conference in 1899, a new era,
he said, has dawned for international arbitration.
Mr. Molt's ideal seems to be a
union of all nations, on the basis
of the union of the North American States; and in the present condition of things he professes to see
the beginning of such a union. The
Hague Conferences, which, it is
now assured, will be held in the
future at regular intervals, he likens
to the old Congress of the Confederacy; in the new Court of Arbitral Justice, which, thanks to., the
zeal of Secretary Knox, is soon to
be established, he sees an image of
our Supreme Court; and therefore
there wants nothing save an international executive, which he thinks
will some day surely be realized,
to the fulfillment of the splendid
dream of the last two lines of
Locksley Hall.
r. Holt, after completing his
lecture, showed some very interesting views of the Hague, and the
surrounding country, portraits of
some of the great peace advocates,
and several amusing cartoons from
the press of various nations.

At a meeting of the freshman
class last Monday afternoon, Clifford A. Wells, of Toronto, Can.,
was elected captain of the 1914
track team with Herbert E. Catlin,
manager. Immediately after being
elected captain, Wells issued a call
for candidates, and there were a
number of freshmen training with
the 'varsity squad every afternoon
last week.
Wells and Sutton are twO runners
who will make the sophomores
hustle in the distance events. Dorsey, Catlin, White, and Barton are
among the candidates for the
dashes. Hinrichs, Wells, Coblentz,
and Liebensperger are training for
the high jump. Yost and Krumrein will probably represent the
freshmen in the broad jump.
Riley and Schreiber will give the
sophomore crack weight throwers
—Novak and Pieper—a hard fight
in the shot-put. Chenoweth, who
played center on the freshman football team, is also showing up well
in practice with the shot.
The freshmen awarded the class
numbers to their class football
squad and to those who succeeded
in getting hands on the cane in the
cane rush. Those who received the
numerals. were: E. Riley, D. Riley,
Dorsey, Catlin, W. Sutton, White,
Howell, Bryan, Hill, Chenoweth,
Schreiber, Barton, Yost, Randall,
Campbell, Hanzsche, Holliday,
Liebensperger, Coblentz, a n d
Bridgman.

BOOK REVIEWS

$1,000 FOR ESSAYISTS

History of Socialism in the United
States. (New Edition.) By Morris
Hillquit. New York: Funk & Wagnalls
Company. Price $1,50 net.

Anti-Saloon League Will Pay for Papers
on What the Liquor Revenue
Costs Baltimore.

With a Socialist mayor, a representative in Congress and a hundren minor state officials in various
parts . of the country, the third
political party in the United States
can, after years of ceaseless effort,
point to something accomplished.
There has been no one event respon-.
sible for the election of these men.
A steady movement which has for
the most part been gradually gaining force is the cause of these
election results.
The new edition of Hillquit's
work which has for seven years
served as the authority on the
Socialist movement in America is
at this juncture peculiarly oppoctune. It is a thoroughly able study
of wide scope and of great theoretical and sociological as well as •
historical value. It traces the
origin and development of Socialism through the many transient
communistic experiments which
have been urged by political dreamers, with a sympathetic treatment
brings it down to the present day,
when the movement is attracting
n:ore attention than it has ever before been accorded in political
circles.
The future, according to Mr.
Hillquit, is an especially bright one.
He believes that "the industrial development is irresistibly preparing,
the ground for a large and vigorous Socialistic movement," and
that if the American voters could
be persuaded that the cause is not
a hopeless one, it would immediately be established as a permanent, important, and perhaps dominant factor in American politics.
But in the concluding paragraph
of the book, there is an admission
which seems to destroy somewhat
the force of the optimistic conclusions. "Many, of the measures," Mr.
Hillquit says, "of industrial, social
and political reform, originally advocated exclusively by the Socialists, are gradually being forced into
the platforms of other parties and
organizations." What is there to
keep us from believing that the
end will be reached by these
means? The history of government
indicates that some of the desires of
the Socialists will ultimately be attained. Soule, such as the income
tax, municipal ownership, and the
initiative and referendum are already in existence. But is it not
more probable that all of these reforms will be gradually brought
about through the agency of the
regular parties than by an organization whose methods and desires are
not at the present time in sympathy
with the spirit of America?
L. R.

University students have an excellent opportunity to add to the information available upon a question
of great local importance and at
the same time to secure an unusual
reward by taking advantage of the
offer made by the Anti-Saloon
League of Maryland of prizes
amounting to $1,000 for the best
essays on what the liquor revenue
costs the City of Baltimore. The
contest closes on April I, 1911,
giving contestants two months and
a half yet in which to work..
So far the number of papers submitted to the League has not come
up to anticipations. "We are
anxious," said Mr. 'William H. Anderson, the secretary, "that there
shall be a goodly number of candidates with real ability, and not
enough have shown up yet to make
it by any means improbable that
any good man who tries may get
the prize."
The conditions of the contest are
as follows:
A prize of five hundred dollars
($500) for the best essay, and
three additional prizes of $250,
$150 and Slop respectively for the
three next best essays on:
"What it costs the people of Baltimore (I) morally, (2) physically,
(3) mentally, (4) financially, and
(5) industrially to secure the million dollars a year which the city
now receives from the liquor traffic
under the high license law."
The contest is open to any person
anywhere except salaried employees of the Anti-Saloon League
of -Maryland. Essays must not exceed 5,000 words. The number of
words must be indicated, and, other
things being equal, brevity will be
considered in making the award.
Facts will count for more than
mere argument. Essays must be
typewritten, double spaced, with
ample margin, on one side of plain
inches, with
white paper 82x
name and address of the writer
securely attached in a sealed envelope.
Essays must be received, postage
-hilly prepaid, by Rev. J. F. Heisse,
D. D., Chairman of the Headquarters Committee, at the League
office, Sol American Building, Baltimore, Md., on or before April
1, 1911. All essays shall become
the property of the League. The
decision will be made by the Headquarters Committee of the AntiSaloon League, or by judges designated by them, and will be announced and the prizes paid as soon
as the essays can be examined and
a decision reached. -

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 16, 1911
ATHLETIC RECORDS FIXED
Committee Reports on Track and Field
Performances by Hopkins Athletes—
Holders of Records and
the Figures.

Hopkins track and field athletic
records have been authoritatively established by the report of the special
committee which since its appointment in 1907 has been engaged
in investigating the performances
of the athletes of the University
for the purpose of compiling
official records for the athletic
board.
The report in full is too long
to publish here. The following
quotation will explain the nature of
the work of the committee:
"The earlier records—i. e., before 1896—if any there were, do
not seem to be preserved in any
obtainable form. This date, however, corresponds practically with
the beginning of the University's
activity in track and field athletics,
and for that reason is taken by
your committee as a starting point
the authenticated performances.
"Out of the material at hand
various difficulties presented themselves, as far as the correctness of
the different marks was concerned.
It became necessary to determine,
as accurately as possible, whether
the track events were properly
timed or judged, as well as to discover if the field performances
were measured with precision and
accuracy—all of which necessitated
the examination of many old programs, records and the like. It is
believed, however, that the results
arrived at represent, as nearly as
possible, the present state of performances. For the correction of
any, the smallest, details your committee will be extremely grateful.
Respectfully submitted,
"G. W. STUART,
"J. H. HUNM,
"J. T. ENGLAND."

German Author To Speak.

Tomorrow (Tuesday evening)
at 8 o'clock there will be a lecture
in McCoy Hall by Ernst Ludwig
reiherr von Wolzogen on "Das
Deutsche Theatre der Gegenwart."
Herr von Wolzogen is a novelist
and dramatist of note and it is
fortunate that we may have the
pleasure of hearing him.
Herr von Wolzogen was born
in Breslau in 1855. From 1876-79
he studied in Strasburg and Leipsic
and later spent a number of years
in Weimar. He went to Berlin in
1882, later to Munich and is now
resident in Darmstadt. He has distinguished himself by his bright
and easily-flowing stories and by
his comedies. Some of his works
are: "Um 13 Uhr in der Christnacht," "Das Dritte Geschlect,"
"Feursnot," (set to music by
Richard Strauss), "Verse aus
Meinem Leben." He has written
also many critical and literary
studies.
